node.title: New banner with cards are added to all pages
node.body:
issue #133 resolved

-Cards like banners are added on every page, like men, women kids, shoes, sales.
-Banner from all pages are responsive.
-For more 'pluggable look' library is used.
-All Images are good high quality
-5-6 different cards are added as banner with effects and slide animation 
-Title and description is meant to be meaningful with images and nav link.
-Every page, every card have unique image, title, description with well relatable meaning...
-On every page changes cards are added, yet code is also kept optimized, with no redundancy.
-Cards can be changed by mouse, or by clicking on a card then using keyboard buttons (to use keyboard focus on card i required)
here is screenshot of banner cards:
![Screenshot (114)](https://github.com/rohan9024/ecommerce/assets/110652247/597d52d2-ad7d-4654-84e0-89157ef5758b)
-page of shoes section
![Screenshot (115)](https://github.com/rohan9024/ecommerce/assets/110652247/c61fd1b3-99d3-482c-ac77-e65d10e0d3ff)
-responsive testing
![Screenshot (116)](https://github.com/rohan9024/ecommerce/assets/110652247/3dd29278-93a9-44d0-87d5-41454acfc616)
![Screenshot (117)](https://github.com/rohan9024/ecommerce/assets/110652247/d53b18bc-d67b-4eba-a25f-35667e7f462a)
-Can change the the cards as slides by both mouse and keyboard 
![Screenshot (118)](https://github.com/rohan9024/ecommerce/assets/110652247/80032e13-e856-43f1-8436-9f217ab20a4d)


please do check my pr, it was soo hard as react newbie 😅but it was so fun also😁

node.title: feat: neuron rotation
node.body:
For each key:
1. extract an orthogonal matrix, model $A$ is the base and model $B$ is the target orientation
2. apply the orthogonal transform immediately

Note: this is pretty slow. On my RTX 3080 it takes me ~3 minutes to merge two models.

node.bodyText: This is actually a lot more complex than meets the eye. We should be determining the svd driver based on the size of the matrix. Different drivers perform faster on smaller/bigger matrices. And in some instances the CPU will out perform the GPU. What exactly is our average matrix size when we call svd?

If we include all keys, it goes form $320^2$ to ~ $20K^2$. As this upper bound isn't really practical, if we exclude all conv layers (which have the largest neurons), the upper bound is ~ $5K^2$. I can list all sizes in a bit, they all are square matrices.
I've never done this before at all, this is all new to me. Appreciate the help. IIUC, this only matters on cuda devices?

all matrices sizes that currently go through svd are listed below:

320x320: 47 keys
640x640: 48 keys
768x768: 94 keys
960x960: 2 keys
1280x1280: 83 keys
2560x2560: 10 keys
3072x3072: 12 keys
5120x5120: 6 keys

I did some benchmarking between jax's svd functions jitted through XLA and pytorch's different drivers on a colab using a v100 (a 3080 is about equal to this in PyTorch Performance), and these were the results.

Basically unless you need full accuracy, even with full_matrices set to true, gesvdj is going to be faster. However the speed you gain comes at the cost of some accuracy, and the potential to not always converge without needing to fall back to gesvd.

I tested gesvdj with fractional alpha a while ago and the error builds up pretty quickly. IIRC it works okay in the non fractional cases (alpha = 0 or alpha = 1). I'll run some tests again to verify this and make sure this was the cause.

It appears that I can't practically merge models using gesvdj, on my 3080 it takes 1m10s to merge a single 3072x3072 key. The full merge might take more than a hour. Maybe the proper merge driver to use is hardware dependent?
stage 1:  11%|█         | 121/1133 [08:28<22:51,  1.36s/it]
shape: torch.Size([3072, 3072])
stage 1:  11%|█         | 125/1133 [09:38<1:46:57,  6.37s/it]
I'll make sure to try it here in a bit on my system.

Apart from taking 57 minutes to merge gesvdj on a RTX 3080, there doesn't seem to be any quality difference between merging using gesvd and gesvdj with alpha=1.0 and beta=0.0:

Unless of course I did not switch the driver correctly. All I did was use the string "gesvdj" instead of "gesvd". All merges were made using --driver cuda
Yeah, something seems wrong on your end, are you sure that PyTorch is seeing your GPU?
Yes my device is setup correctly and I can see that it uses cuda:0 during the merge. I don't have any other cuda hardware on my system.
I'll try updating pytorch to 2.1.x and see if that fixes it. Currently my version is 2.0.1 compiled with cuda support.
Updating did not increase merge speed with gesvdj.

How long does it take on your end to merge the same set of models with gesvd and then with gesvdj? I understand that the benchmarks above indicate that gesvdj should be faster, but I wonder if we should run benchmarks against the particular type of data we would see with model merging in case gesvdj runs faster or slower depending on what the value of the input is.

I'm getting 1.3 sec/it to 1.8it/sec with gesvd.  gesvdj does seem slower. My guess is that our matrices aren't converging. Now, do we need the full matrix from svd? Setting that to false would help speed things up as well.

Does the full_matrices parameter even have an effect when the input matrix is square? But even if it has an effect, I believe we do. Basically, what we're doing here is solving the procrustes problem where the points are the neurons from A and B. We need $U$ and $V^T$ to be (square) unitary matrices. If computing reduced matrices shrinks $U$ and $V$ in width, I'm not sure the resulting $UV^T$ would necessarily be unitary.

Hm, according to the docs, it seems that the columns of $U$ and $V$ should be orthonormal with full_matrices=False. IIUC, $UV^T$ should then be a orthogonal matrix. Experimentally, that seems to be the case. I'll test if there's any quality loss/drawback to this and how much quicker it is.

There is no apparent quality loss, so I'll commit full_matrices=False.
left image is full_matrices=False, right image is full_matrices=True

Actually I don't see a major speedup with full_matrices=False. I'll try to remove neuron dimensions that are more similar. One idea I had was to lower the similarity threshold during the comparison so that the values in a dimension closer to 0 are discarded before applying SVD.

If we have a lot of similar matrices, it might be worth it to try jax instead of pytorch and use the XLA accelerated svd functions there. From what I understanding, the caching will make repeated runs of similar data faster.

I just did a speed test on CPU and the performance is significantly better. With 4 threads, CPU was able to get to key 943/1145 in only 5 minutes using the default driver (gesvdj) before the process ran out of memory. (I use WSL for my SD env).

Also, I am currently having an issue where moving beyond stage 1 causes a crash with the following backtrace on cpu.
stage 1:  98%|██████████████████████████████████████████████████████████▌ | 1105/1131 [04:51<00:06,  3.79it/s]
Using already loaded model bbwm_Aurora.safetensors [431eebe43e]: done in 8.9s (send model to device: 8.9s)
*** API error: POST: http://127.0.0.1:7860/bbwm/merge-models {'error': 'RuntimeError', 'detail': '', 'body': '', 'errors': 'torch.linalg.eig: input tensor should not contain infs or NaNs.'}

      File "/home/maria/stable-diffusion/stable-diffusion-webui/venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/sd_meh/merge_methods.py", line 272, in fractional_matrix_power

    RuntimeError: torch.linalg.eig: input tensor should not contain infs or NaNs.

---

on CPU [...] the performance is significantly better

5 minutes is the time it takes on my system to merge on cuda with the gesvd driver. I'll see if I get a speed discount on cpu with gesvdj with 10 threads.

Also, I am currently having an issue where moving beyond stage 1 causes a crash with the following backtrace on cpu.

Although I am not testing rotation through the bbmw API, even though I haven't seen this error before, it is probably caused by the merge method and not the API. It seems to be near the end of stage 1 (still in it because the exception is raised inside the merge method). It seems to be caused by imprecision in the svd calculation. It is possible that full_matrices=False is the cause, if it isn't because we are using the gesvdj driver on cpu.

Reading from the docs, it doesn't seem to be possible to pick a specific driver if the device is not cuda:

The driver kwarg may be used in CUDA with a cuSOLVER backend to choose the algorithm used to compute the SVD. The choice of a driver is a trade-off between accuracy and speed.

Sometimes torch.linalg.cond(a_neurons.T @ b_neurons) is very large (~1.0e+15) and at other times it is < 1000. According to the docs:


If A is well-conditioned (its condition number is not too large), or you do not mind some precision loss.

For a general matrix: ‘gesvdj’ (Jacobi method)
If A is tall or wide (m >> n or m << n): ‘gesvda’ (Approximate method)




So gesvda is definitely not appropriate, and gesvdj seems to be sometimes (but most keys seem to have a large cond experimentally). Calculating torch.linalg.cond takes a bit of time, so it may or may not be worth it to switch to gesvdj conditionally.

Do you know how I can install pytorch_xla? I'm not able to run the pip install here:
https://github.com/pytorch/xla/#getting-started

Looking in links: https://storage.googleapis.com/libtpu-releases/index.html
Requirement already satisfied: torch~=2.1.0 in d:\src\meh-dev\venv\lib\site-packages (2.1.1+cu118)
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement torch_xla[tpu]~=2.1.0 (from versions: 1.0)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for torch_xla[tpu]~=2.1.0

The quickest run I could get was under 5 minutes (~4m45s) using --work_device cuda and --threads 10 with the current code in the PR. IIUC threads are useful here to reduce the overhead of tensors being copied to another device.
So I actually did a test with a full matrices turned on and the issue still occurred. So I'm not sure what is causing it.

Do you know how I can install pytorch_xla? I'm not able to run the pip install here: https://github.com/pytorch/xla/#getting-started

Looking in links: https://storage.googleapis.com/libtpu-releases/index.html
Requirement already satisfied: torch~=2.1.0 in d:\src\meh-dev\venv\lib\site-packages (2.1.1+cu118)
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement torch_xla[tpu]~=2.1.0 (from versions: 1.0)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for torch_xla[tpu]~=2.1.0



So when I referenced XLA, I was using it in the context of JAX, where you precompile your function using the XLA JIT with JAX, and then go from there. You can interoperate PyTorch and JAX using DLpacks so there shouldn't be any issues with type compatibility, the notation might get a little messy though.

By the way full_matrices=False doesn't produce a reduced SVD when $m=n$ ($m$ and $n$ being the width and height of the svd input). That's why it didn't seem to affect generation speed. We might want to remove it as it doesn't really change anything, since the input to the svd is always a square covariance matrix here.

So I did complete a full merge on CUDA, and didn't receive the error. I think it has something to do with trying to move models between the CPU and GPU, interacting with WebUI keeping models loaded in memory. Is there sanity checking when the models are loaded to ensure that they have been moved to CPU if the work_device is set to CPU?

Before merging, when assembling the merge args, the weights are sent to the requested device:

  
    
      meh/sd_meh/merge.py
    
    
        Lines 465 to 466
      in
      2780321
    
  
  
    

        
          
           "a": thetas["model_a"][key].to(work_device), 
        

        
          
           "b": thetas["model_b"][key].to(work_device), 
        
    
  


note that if work_device is None, it takes the value of device:

  
    
      meh/sd_meh/merge.py
    
    
        Lines 371 to 372
      in
      2780321
    
  
  
    

        
          
           if work_device is None: 
        

        
          
               work_device = device 
        
    
  


So IIUC, it shouldn't be a device issue.

I think I found the culprit.
It seems that on CPU there isn't enough precision sometimes, which leads too $U$ or $V^T$ having a determinant of 0. This is not what SVD should output, $U$ and $V^T$ should always be orthogonal transforms, which implies $|det U| = |det V^T| = 1$.
When the determinant of $U$ or $V^T$ is 0, then this line divides by 0:
        u[:, -1] /= torch.det(u) * torch.det(v_t)
So the last column of u sometimes is filled with infinities. Then, when trying to compute the eigenvalues of the matrix, an error is then raised.
As noted below, while this prevents the entire merge from raising an error, rotations with invalid determinants still result in a broken merge. I went the other direction and raised an error instead.

node.title: CC-859 add stripe invoice details
node.body:
**Checklist**:

- [x] I've thoroughly self-reviewed my changes
- [x] I've added tests for my changes, unless they affect admin-only areas (or are otherwise not worth testing)
- [x] I've verified any visual changes using Percy (add a commit with `[percy]` in the message to trigger)

node.bodyText: Our naming pattern is to use handleClick for handlers within the class, and @onClick for args - to be consistent I'd name this arg @onStartMembershipButtonClick
Let's add a space between the service declarations and the rest (not sure how we ended up without it here)

Feel like this whole function could be far simpler:
return {
  pricingFrequency: this.selectedPricingFrequency,
  regionalDiscount: this.shouldApplyRegionalDiscount ? this.model.regionalDiscount : null,
  earlyBirdDiscountEnabled: this.selectedPricingFrequency == "yearly" && this.user.isEligibleForEarlyBirdDiscount,
  referralDiscountEnabled: this.selectedPricingFrequency == "yearly" && this.user.isEligibleForReferralDiscount
}

node.title: build: bump core
node.body:
Update the `v2-core` branch to main and add the `transferable` parameter from this [PR](https://github.com/sablier-labs/v2-core/pull/668).

Notes:
1. I have not changed yet the `package.json` file for the new `v2-core` version because it's not released on npm. Installing it as a github package would not work due to [prepack](https://github.com/sablier-labs/v2-core/blob/e626e6f9f9c460a8b42b3501de71debb684965b3/package.json#L60) from core. It would fail as seen [here](https://app.warp.dev/block/dfG3EBwso2os6NbedCqQuh).
2. At the moment we are deploying the core contracts in the fork tests because using the old version of them would not work due to the new boolean added.

node.bodyText: looks good except for that gas optimization
We need to define this before merkleRoot to save gas by tight packing.

Update: it is not true that storage variables are tightly packed like struct fields.

https://chat.openai.com/share/67619484-f686-4d11-8cac-cb9e8d4ca1ce
https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/q/155029/24693
lgtm

ChatGPT seems to have given an incorrect response here. Storage variables are also tightly packed.
It's true that because of dealing with reduced-size variables in the same slot, changing the value of y will consume more gas (~100 in comparison) in the case of contract B, but it will also save gas (~16,000 in comparison) when setting it the first time. It depends on the use case and how many times each variable is read or written.
However, in the above code, it does not matter because immutable variables are part of the creation code and not of the contract storage.

https://docs.soliditylang.org/en/latest/internals/layout_in_storage.html
https://docs.soliditylang.org/en/latest/contracts.html#immutable

However, in the above code, it does not matter because immutable variables are part of the creation code and not of the contract storage.

yes, this is correct, that's what i've told him privately

node.title: Show info header only on first command

node.bodyText: Is this the best way to do this? In other places, we use instance/class variables:

I am not happy about it either but this was the only way I could implement it.
I tried this at first. But when we run a command (run CLI start method) in another command, we get into a new instance, and we don't have access to the earlier instance variables.

This raises a WTF...
Where in the world did you get the ObjectSpace idea?
Counting object instances is a total hack.
You could probably set a static counter on or boolean on the CPL class. In other words, instance variable on the class, not the instance.
Use a class instance variable (aka static) on the cpl class.
https://chat.openai.com/share/e62c8db1-0622-4617-b8a6-5c3a4d82f387
"already" feels redundant. showed_info_header already gets the point across.
Can we not just call show_info_header directly without Cpl::Cli, since we're inside of the class?

No.
It seems we are defining instance methods for each command. If we want to call static methods from instance methods, we must prefix it with the class. This confusion was one of the reasons I tried to find another way to implement this feature.
I can replace Cpl::Cli with self.class, but I think this is clearer.
Looks good to me, just one thing I missed about initializing the variable, but no need for re-review.
We don't need to initialize it.

You're right.
Maybe it would be even better to move show_info_header to a helper then, because it would be easier to call it. But the current way works too, so up to you. I'll approve the PR.
Since we use it once, let's keep it here. Let's move it there when we need to. Agree?

Done! I removed it.
I thought an explicit default value assignment would be better.

node.title: Voice functionality added with Whisper
node.body: Added voice functionality with whisper. Implemented a `--voice` command-line flag using `argparse`.

node.title: 整理: 疑問形 upspeak の単純化
node.body:
## 内容
概要: 疑問形 upspeak 処理の単純化によるリファクタリング  

ネストの解消・処理の簡素化によってリファクタリングをおこなった。  

## 関連 Issue
part of #897

## Reviewer 向け情報
3つの関数ネストを削除したため、diff が機能していません。  
commit ごとに 1 つの関数を削除したため、レビュー時には commit log を参照していただければ幸いです。

node.bodyText:
この変更ですが、一般的には関数側にフラグを与えてどうするかを委ねるよりも、単一処理を行う関数にするのが良いとされていると思います。
ChatGPTに両者のメリットを聞いてみた感じ、この返答が自分の考えと近かったです。
https://chat.openai.com/share/cb0a7a43-fbff-4876-801a-921c90ed5618
何かこうしている意図があれば知りたいです！

一般的には ... 単一処理を行う関数にするのが良い

👍
一般論として同意です。

こうしている意図があれば

「upspeak 適用有無含めて 1 機能とみなし、厳密にテストできるから」が意図/理由です。
現在の test_synthesis_engine_base.py では spy に用いて .synthesis() の一部をテストしています。

  
    
      voicevox_engine/test/test_synthesis_engine_base.py
    
    
        Lines 214 to 218
      in
      831d28a
    
  
  
    

        
          
           self.synthesis_engine.synthesis( 
        

        
          
               query, 0, enable_interrogative_upspeak=enable_interrogative_upspeak 
        

        
          
           ) 
        

        
          
           # _synthesis_implの第一引数に与えられたqueryを検証 
        

        
          
           actual = self.synthesis_engine._synthesis_impl.call_args[0][0].accent_phrases 
        
    
  



  
    
      voicevox_engine/test/test_synthesis_engine_base.py
    
    
        Lines 255 to 259
      in
      831d28a
    
  
  
    

        
          
           self.create_synthesis_test_base( 
        

        
          
               text="これはありますか？", 
        

        
          
               expected=expected, 
        

        
          
               enable_interrogative_upspeak=False, 
        

        
          
           ) 
        
    
  


このテスト対象領域が「upspeak 適用有無 + upspeak適用」つまり今回切り出された apply_interrogative_upspeak() に相当するコードです。
現在のテストではこのコードを enable_interrogative_upspeak フラグ値を変えながら幅広いパターンでテストしています。この幅広さはupspeak有無のバグが品質に大きな影響を与えるためだと思われます。
#899 で議論されたように .synthesis() の入力設定全パターンテストは不可能です。
これが理由で、フラグを外に出すと現行の「enable_interrogative_upspeak フラグ値を変えながら幅広いパターン」を捨てることになります。
enable_interrogative_upspeak フラグを upspeak 量を調整する何かと見做してしまえば、apply_interrogative_upspeak() の引数に調整設定値が入るのはそこまで違和感無いと思います。
よって upspeak適用有無含めて 1 機能とみなすのは（少なくとも）おかしなことではなく、他のメリット・デメリットでフラグを引数にするか否か決めて良いことになります。
これら観点を総合した結果、適用有無含め1機能と見做して現行の幅広いテストを保持することが最善と考え、一般論とは異なる切り出し方をしています。
追記:
将来の方向性として、

#897 が進行して .synthesis() と ._synthesis_impl() が統合
query_to_decoder_feature() 内へ本 PR の apply_interrogative_upspeak() を移植
他の apply 関数達と並ぶ

を想定しています（下コードは最終状態のイメージ）
def query_to_decoder_feature(query) -> tuple[ndarray, ndarray]:
    accent_phrases = query.accent_phrases
    # 設定を適用する
    accent_phrases = apply_interrogative_upspeak(accent_phrases, query) # query内upspeakフラグ
    moras = apply_prepost_silence(to_flatten_moras(accent_phrases), query)
    moras = apply_speed_scale(moras, query)
    moras = apply_pitch_scale(moras, query)
    ...

なるほどです！！
少なくとも今のPRのapply_interrogative_upspeak関数は、queryクラス（つまり関数の責務範囲外）にenable_interrogative_upspeakがあることを想定しないべきだと思います。この関数だけ見た場合に、なぜこのフラグがあるのかわからないかなと。
queryそのものを渡す設計を予定しているのであれば話は別でした。いったんNOTEコメントが有ると良いのかなと！
コメントを追加してマージさせていただこうと思います！

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
                """必要に応じて各アクセント句の末尾へ疑問形モーラ（同一母音・継続長 0.15秒・音高↑）を付与する"""
          
          
            
                """必要に応じて各アクセント句の末尾へ疑問形モーラ（同一母音・継続長 0.15秒・音高↑）を付与する"""
          
          
            
                # NOTE: 将来的にAudioQueryインスタンスを引数にする予定
LGTM！！！

node.title: Kube-proxy/nftables: allow "numgen inc"
node.body:
This makes the nftables proxier distribute traffic in the same way as proxy-mode=ipvs with the "rr" scheduler


#### What type of PR is this?

/kind feature
/sig network
/area kube-proxy

#### What this PR does / why we need it:

Existing users of proxy-mode=ipvs may feel more comfortable if they can keep the round-robin distribution when upgrading to proxy-mode=nftables.

It should be noted that the same limitation applied for nftables with "random inc" as for ipvs/rr: the individual kube-proxy instances on the nodes are not coordinated, but distribute individually. And different schedulers are not possible, as in "ipvs".

#### Which issue(s) this PR fixes:

N/A

#### Special notes for your reviewer:

For start this is a PoC.

A more suitable name than `numgen` should probably be used in the proxier structure. Trying to look into the future, one might expect some new features in nftables, like maglev-hashing", and make it possible to configure those future things without altering the config API, just use a new value for some distribution parameter.

#### Does this PR introduce a user-facing change?

```release-note
Allow users to configure the distribution in proxy-mode=nftables to mimic proxy-mode=ipvs with round-robin
```

#### Additional documentation e.g., KEPs (Kubernetes Enhancement Proposals), usage docs, etc.:

node.bodyText: this is going to be a bit of bikeshedding, but random seems to be a better default since is the one used by cilium and kube-proxy iptables, that I are used more than ivps https://gist.github.com/aojea/5f82db3ba5f1efd59bb73f4b28614a6a

I kind of agree. Random is random, but people expect too much of other schedulers, even "rr". Like the endless discussion of "initial distribution", mentioned for instance in #121591 (comment). Even maglev-hashing doesn't work out-of-the-box in the way people expect.

No plan at the moment. I just read the nft doc's and saw that it can be done. Easily.
But I can't say I have any strong opinions about it, except that is may make some current users of ipvs more comfortable with the upgrade as mentioned in the description. But people may select ipvs for other reasons than "rr", e.g. get rid of the "probability chain" in iptables, that can look horrible for many endpoints, or simply that they know ipvs and it's easier to understand (my case). Or they want another scheduler, which can't be supported by nftables anyway.

I made some experiments of my own with K8s load-balancing, but without any http considerations, only plain tcp connects, at: https://github.com/uablrek/xcluster-ovls/tree/main/k8s-load-balancing
The hardest part was to create the table with Unix/Linux commands, please see:
https://github.com/uablrek/xcluster-ovls/blob/510cca913b632ae0a8506c45bf69d92bc1e6373e/k8s-load-balancing/k8s-load-balancing.sh#L72
But yes, my thought was a config option.

ChatGPT thinks IPTables proxy uses round-robbin algorithm, directing new requests to next destination in the list of pods.  Maybe that is what people think/expect in general - round-robin rather than random 🤔
https://chat.openai.com/share/20271990-883b-476b-b5b0-3c2d2b7efbaf

It should be configurable. For now random, round-robin and hash could be supported, https://wiki.nftables.org/wiki-nftables/index.php/Load_balancing. I think someone out there is already implementing maglev-hashing. But it may be a good idea to keep it simple, and just do random. After all, it has worked fine for the vast majority of K8s users.
I advocate for trying to keep the same behavior as in iptables, but @danwinship is leading this feature, let's see what he thinks

node.title: AGDR/ Configure Overview section
node.body: ## WHAT configure Overview section of the Admin Growth Diagnostic Reports to aggregate and display data from the backend ## WHY now that the necessary APIs are available, we want to configure them to feed into the frontend UI ## HOW - add a bunch of logic for making the various API calls and then aggregating the data once they are all receive - update styling of the table **just a note that there are quite a few snapshots that were updated-- this is because I moved the `DataTable` header name inside of a element for more styling flexibility** ### Screenshots (If applicable. Also, please censor any sensitive data) ### Notion Card Links (Please provide links to any relevant Notion card(s) relevant to this PR.) https://www.notion.so/quill/Admin-Diagnostic-Growth-Report-Overview-Frontend-8e22794d03f345af85b1d95a62e77098?pvs=4 PR Checklist | Your Answer ------------ | ------------- Have you added and/or updated tests? | yes Have you deployed to Staging? | yes Self-Review: Have you done an initial self-review of the code below on Github? | yes Spec Review: Have you reviewed the spec and ensured this meets requirements and/or matches design mockups? | yes

node.bodyText: @anathomical I noticed this misspelling-- is there anywhere else I need to worry about updating this value? (I already updated the PUSHER_EVENT_KEY in the OverviewSection frontend file and didn't find anywhere else when searching the codebase, but I wanted to check with you just to be sure)

I was trying to use the passedData convention we use in some other test files to stub the incoming data(i.e. https://github.com/empirical-org/Empirical-Core/blob/07fc91f79f408045129e496356cb61dddfb2842c/services/QuillLMS/client/app/bundles/PremiumHub/components/canvas/container.tsx#L13), but I kept hitting some issues. Since this is time sensitive and I want to give Peter S the chance to start testing ASAP, I opted to punt on adding more thorough testing in a later PR.
@eadams17 Good catch.  I think those should be the only two places where that value is defined: once on the front-end and once on the back-end.
There's a lot of really good work in here -- just a couple of places I think we need to clean things up before they're ready to go to production.

I think I would just write this as .timeframe-filter.disabled .dropdown .dropdown__control .dropdown__value-container .dropdown__single-value { color: #7f7f7f } to avoid all the nesting. Also, should that color be a variable?
I'm okay with it not being in this PR, but I think it should probably be the next one (can you work on the tests while Peter Sharkey does his review?)

This function is really hard for me to parse. I think we need to split out some interior functions and work on formatting for readability. I think this is a good use case for getting help from ChatGPT -- here's an initial stab at it that might be useful: https://chat.openai.com/c/97307d69-7fcd-4b56-9c38-f8e884c5be4d. I think we also probably want some tests specific to this method (the same way we would about this object if it were being sent up from a controller).
"our guide" is duplicated in the last sentence on this line.

All the ternary logic in here is effectively duplicated and feels a little messy. I think we should do something like:
const performanceButtons = [
  {
    tab: OVERVIEW,
    displayName: 'Performance Overview',
    inactiveIconSrc: barChartGreySrc,
    activeIconSrc: barChartWhiteIconSrc
  },
  ...
]

Then iterate through each of them to generate the button elements in their own function.
Should these querystrings be constants?
Love the clean up here.
It would be good to have these numbers as constants so it's clear what they mean.
A couple of minor notes, but overall this looks good to me.
If we're going to leave this commented out after a merge, we should probably add a // TODO:  note to make it easier to find this later.
I think you can use toString().padLeft(2, '0') instead of adding these if length === 1 conditions.

I think this conditional is fine as-is, but as far as I know it should be impossible for a row to have a postDiagnosticScore but not a preDiagnosticScore, so I think practically speaking you can just make this if (!postDiagnosticScore) if you wanted, but like I said, it's fine as-is.
Totally dig these as constants.
Given that all of these widths seem to be the same value, I wonder if this shouldn't also be a constant even if it's not from a shared file??

So this isn't currently in the back-end, but reviewing this suggests to me that we should also have groupByValue in here.  Let's just do that in a separate PR, though, to avoid adding complexity to this one.
good call! I'll update. I already flagged the hex code to Jack so that he can map it to a variable so just waiting for that (it's used quite a bit around the codebase)
love that suggestion-- I'll make this update
yeah, I can make these constants
that makes sense-- I'll update to be more succinct
sounds good to me!
@emilia-friedberg I can't seem to access the link-- can you maybe send the prompt you inputted so I can have better context?

The refactor you did with that function is so much easier to parse (and will be easier to debug if we ever need to now) -- beautiful work! Love the tests, too. I flagged one small thing I think may have been an error in the refactor but I don't need to review again. Thank you so much for doing all that. Excited to see this ship!
love these tests!
should these two have activeTab === tab as the condition instead of tab === OVERVIEW?
ahh yeah, good catch! I had resolved it in my other branch but not here
